title: How Do Immunostimulants Work? - Uses, Side Effects, Drug Names
author: Medical Author Nazneen Memon; BHMS; PGDCR Medical; Pharmacy Editor Sarfaroj Khan; PGD Health Operations
description: Immunostimulants (immunostimulators) are drugs that stimulate the immune system by increasing the activity of any of its components.
cleaned_text: HOW DO IMMUNOSTIMULANTS WORK? Immunostimulants (immunostimulators) are drugs that stimulate the [immune system](https://www.rxlist.com/immune_system/definition.htm) by increasing the activity of any of its components. The [immune](https://www.rxlist.com/immune/definition.htm) system is a complex network of cells, tissues, and organs. Together, they help the body fight infections and diseases. Sipuleucel-T (an [immunosuppressant](https://www.rxlist.com/immunosuppressant/definition.htm)) is used to treat certain types Another immunostimulant the United States Administration](https://www.rxlist.com/food_and_drug_administration/definition.htm) ( [FDA](https://www.rxlist.com/fda/definition.htm)) approval for [therapeutic](https://www.rxlist.com/therapeutic/definition.htm) [vaccination](https://www.rxlist.com/vaccination/definition.htm) to elicit immune responses against a wide variety of HIV antigens. These medications are also called personalized [autologous](https://www.rxlist.com/autologous/definition.htm) cellular [immunotherapy](https://www.rxlist.com/immunotherapy/definition.htm) (a type of [medication](https://www.rxlist.com/medication/definition.htm) prepared using cells from the [patient](https://www.rxlist.com/patient/definition.htm)'s own [blood](https://www.rxlist.com/blood/definition.htm)). The two main categories of immunostimulants are: - Specific immunostimulants: stimulate an [immune response](https://www.rxlist.com/immune_response/definition.htm)to a specific [antigen](https://www.rxlist.com/antigen/definition.htm)(a [toxin](https://www.rxlist.com/toxin/definition.htm)or other foreign [substance](https://www.rxlist.com/substance/definition.htm)which induces an immune response in the body) such as [vaccines](https://www.rxlist.com/vaccines/definition.htm). - Nonspecific immunostimulants: act irrespective of antigenic [specificity](https://www.rxlist.com/specificity/definition.htm)and are used in [immunodeficiency](https://www.rxlist.com/immunodeficiency/definition.htm)and [chronic](https://www.rxlist.com/chronic/definition.htm)infections. - Immunostimulants are [prescription](https://www.rxlist.com/prescription/definition.htm)-only medicines and are administered as a suspension (liquid) to be injected over about 60 minutes into a [vein](https://www.rxlist.com/vein/definition.htm)once every two weeks for a total of three doses. About three days before each dose of sipuleucel-T injection is to be given, a sample of white blood cells is collected at a [cell](https://www.rxlist.com/cell/definition.htm)collection center using a procedure called leukapheresis (a [process](https://www.rxlist.com/process/definition.htm)that removes the white blood cells from the body). This sample is then sent to the manufacturer and combined with a [protein](https://www.rxlist.com/protein/definition.htm)to prepare a dose of sipuleucel-T injection. Immunostimulants work in the following ways: - They cause the body's immune system to fight [cancer](https://www.rxlist.com/cancer/definition.htm)cells. - Sipuleucel-T selectively targets the [prostate](https://www.rxlist.com/prostate/definition.htm)-specific antigen known as [prostatic acid phosphatase](https://www.rxlist.com/prostatic_acid_phosphatase/definition.htm)( [PAP](https://www.rxlist.com/pap/definition.htm)), an antigen that is expressed in around 95% of prostate cancers. - Sipuleucel-T vaccine is based on the concept of antigen-presenting cells (APCs). These cells present antigens in a form that T cells can recognize. - It works through APCs to stimulate T-cell immune response targeted against PAP. HOW ARE IMMUNOSTIMULANTS USED? - Immunostimulant drug sipuleucel-T was approved minimally [symptomatic](https://www.rxlist.com/symptomatic/definition.htm)metastatic [hormone](https://www.rxlist.com/hormone/definition.htm)- [refractory](https://www.rxlist.com/refractory/definition.htm)prostate cancer. [HIV vaccine](https://www.rxlist.com/consumer_hiv_vaccine/drugs-condition.htm)is awaiting FDA approval to treat HIV antigens. WHAT ARE SIDE EFFECTS OF IMMUNOSTIMULANTS?
